Package com.l2h1.tamagotchi.model

Class LivingEntity

java.lang.Object
com.l2h1.tamagotchi.model.Entity
com.l2h1.tamagotchi.model.LivingEntity
All Implemented Interfaces:
JSONable
public class LivingEntity extends Entity
A class representing a living entity, which extends the abstract Entity class. Living entities encapsulate various states such as health, hunger, entertainment, hygiene, sociability, and fatigue. But this class, just as the backend logic, has been made as modular as possible, so that any future developer can add, modify or remove a state at will, or modify its simulation logic.

Living entities provide functionality to manage and monitor their states, as well as methods for simulation, JSON serialization and states values listeners.

See Also:

  • Method Details

    • devLogs

      public void devLogs()
      This method is only available in the dev version, and should only be used for debugging purposes. It displays all the entity's state values at a given time.
      Since:
      dev version

    • checkStates

      public void checkStates()
      Starts the verification procedure for all entity states. Verification consists of the following sequence:
      • check whether each state has a critical value
      • add each critical state to the entity's list of critical states; respectively, remove each stable state from the entity's list of critical states
      • call OnStateValueChangedListener.onStateCritical(State.CriticalType) on the type that has become critical; respectively, call OnStateValueChangedListener.onStateStable(State.StateType) on the type that has become stable again
      • check whether one of the states is killing the entity
      • call OnEntityDeadListener.onEntityDead(State.DeathType) on the state that has killed the entity
      checkStates() must be called every time the entity needs to be updated for its states, whether during a simulation or after a simple change of state value. The method must also be called if you wish to check that the entity is still alive, especially if an OnEntityDeadListener is waiting for the entity death to perform an action.
      See Also:
      • State
      • State.isValueCritical()
      • State.isOver()

    • passTime

      public void passTime()

    • passTime

      public void passTime(double secs)
      Represents the passage of time for all entity states for given seconds. Note once again that the variations in the values of the entity's states are a function of ticks; and that one tick = 15 seconds. Calling this method for a time of less than 15 seconds will therefore produce nothing.

      During simulation, whether passive or active, the passage of time is simulated in such a way as to decrease the values of each state of the entity according to each tick passed. The malus generated by critical states is also taken into account, so that with each passage of time, the values of the entity's states drop more or less according to the entity's critical states.

      Parameters:
      secs - the number of seconds representing the life simulation time passed by the entity

    • getStates

      public Map<State.StateType,State> getStates()
      Retrieves the entity's states Map. More precisely, returns a Map that associates State.StateType objects as keys with State objects as values.
      Returns:
      the entity's Map of key-values of type State.StateType - State

    • hasCriticalState

      public boolean hasCriticalState(State.CriticalType criticalType)
      Returns whether one of the entity's critical states is of the specified type.
      Parameters:
      criticalType - the State.CriticalType of the state to check whether the entity has it or not
      Returns:
      true if one of the entity's critical states is of the type specified, otherwise false
